title: Robert De Niro, Al Pacino and Martin Scorsese celebrate The Irishman
text:
Best friends, best friends, best friends (Picture: DANIEL LEAL-OLIVAS/AFP via Getty Images)

Martin Scorsese, Al Pacino and Robert De Niro were the best of friends while attending The Irishman’s photocall in London.

We couldn’t get over how close the ultimate trio looked as they posed for cameras at The Mayfair Hotel.

The three are among Hollywood’s most famous and celebrated filmmakers and actors in the world and watching them hang out was the best thing we could ask for.

Robert, 76, looked dapper as he watched Martin Scorsese embrace Al Pacino as if they haven’t seen each other in 20 years.

The trio got together to celebrate The Irishman, which hits UK screens on 8 November, will be the latest gangster film from the director.

And who better to direct a gangster film than the man behind 1995’s Casino himself.

Robert De Niro has been working with Martin since the ’70s (Picture: Doug Peters/EMPICS)

Umm, how cute? (Picture: DANIEL LEAL-OLIVAS/AFP via Getty Images)

Thanks to visual effects that make Robert, Joe Pesci and Al younger, the movie spans decades of their characters’ lives.

The Irishman sees Robert star as Sheeran, a mafia hitman and high-ranking Teamster official.

Sheeran, in real life, was an American labour union official who was accused of having links to the infamous Buffalo Crime Family.

Shortly before he died, Sheeran had confessed to killing the President of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Jimmy Hoffa (played by Al), but his disappearance remained unsolved.

Thanks to visual effects that make Robert, Joe Pesci and Al younger, the movie spans decades of their characters’ lives.

The Irishman will hit Netflix in November (Picture: Netflix)

Speaking on the de-ageing CGI effects, Martin said: ‘If we made the film earlier they could have played younger but at a certain point we missed that and then they said “use younger actors” and I said, “what’s the point of that?”

‘CGI is really an evolution of make-up, you accept certain norms in make-up, you know he’s not that old, she’s not that young, you accept the illusion.’

Al, who rose to fame in The Godfather, added: ‘I saw the film without any work, without effects and it was fine. I’m not the only one who felt that way. I think it’s really good we have it, we have this potential and it’s exercised in the film.

‘In the old days they put an actor we all knew and loved and put grey hair on him and we would be like “oh he got older”, and you accept it because it’s in the story.’
